answer: Yes, the policy will cover inpatient hospitalization expenses for a fractured hip resulting from an accidental fall. Since the policy was issued one week prior to the incident and the treatment was emergency in nature, the insured is continuously covered without any break, and the hospitalization is required for the medical management of the injury.
ground_truth: Accidental injuries are covered immediately without waiting periods. Hip fracture due to fall is an accident (sudden, unforeseen, involuntary event caused by external, visible and violent means). Emergency hospitalization for fracture treatment is covered under In-patient Hospitalization Treatment.

ground_truth: Maternity expenses including normal delivery, complicated deliveries, and caesarean sections are permanently excluded (Code-Excl18). Only ectopic pregnancy is covered as an exception. Duration of policy or plan type does not affect this exclusion. Decision: REJECTED.

answer: A cumulative bonus is an increase in your insurance coverage (Sum Insured) that the insurer gives you without raising your premium. It's like a reward for not making claims. The bonus can increase up to 100% of your original Sum Insured. However, if you make a claim, the bonus may decrease by 10% in the next policy year. Also, for family floater policies, the bonus applies to the entire family's coverage.
ground_truth: Cumulative Bonus (Domestic Cover only): If policy renewed without break and NO claim made in preceding year, Sum Insured increases by 20% of base Sum Insured annually. Maximum cumulative increase: 100% of base Sum Insured. If claim made in any year with bonus, bonus reduces by 20% in next renewal (base Sum Insured preserved). Bonus does not reduce sum insured when used. Not a claim response - benefit explanation.

answer: Yes, the policy will cover inpatient hospitalization expenses incurred due to a fracture sustained in a slip-and-fall accident, as long as the hospitalization is required for the medical management of the injury. Since the policy was issued five months prior to the incident, it is active and should cover the expenses.
ground_truth: Accidental injury requiring emergency hospitalization is covered under Base Cover 1 - Emergency Accidental Hospitalization. answer: No, the policy does not cover inpatient hospitalization expenses for dengue fever if the policy was purchased within the waiting period for pre-existing diseases. Dengue fever would be considered a pre-existing condition if you had symptoms or were diagnosed before the policy's start date. The policy excludes coverage for pre-existing diseases and their direct complications until the waiting period is over.
ground_truth: Dengue is an illness/disease, not an accident. Base cover only includes Emergency Accidental Hospitalization, which covers accidents only. For illness coverage, Endorsement no.1 - Emergency Medical Expenses (Illness/Disease) must be opted and paid for separately. Even if opted, policy is only 3 weeks old, within 30-day waiting period for illness (General Exclusion 4). Decision: REJECTED.

This means you will have to pay 10% of the costs, and the insurance will cover the remaining 90%.
ground_truth: Diabetes and hypertension are pre-existing diseases (diagnosed/treated within 48 months before policy). General Exclusion 2 excludes pre-existing conditions.
